nothing on record to show that the viscera sample was properly during the aforesaid period.Though no poison could be in the viscera sample of the the factual position of the case in hand by the of the and the inquest report go to show that death of Tuli had occurred otherwise than under normal The inquest report lends to the prosecution case as it appears therefrom that death of Tuli was caused by consuming poison.At the time of inquest it was noted that froth was coming out from the mouth and nose of the The expression normal apparently means natural death.In other words, the expression otherwise than under normal means death not being in the usual course but apparently under In the case of Bhupendra Versus State of Madhya Pradesh reported in 2013(4) Crimes 480(Supreme Court) it was held that chemical examination of viscera is not mandatory in every case of dowry death.For the purpose of Section 304 B IPC mere fact of an unnatural death is sufficient to invite a presumption under Section 113B of the Evidence Act.The relevant 26 of the judgment in Bhupendras case (supra) is quoted These decisions clearly bring out that a chemical examination of the viscera is not mandatory in every case of a dowry death even when a viscera report is sought for, its absence is not necessarily fatal to the case of the prosecution when an unnatural death punishable under Section 304-B of the IPC or under Section 306 of the IPC takes place in a case of an unnatural death Section 304-B of the IPC (read with the presumption under Section 113-B of the Evidence Act, 1872) or Section 306 of the IPC(read with the presumption under Section 113- A of the Evidence Act, 1872) as long as there is of poisoning, of the poison may not be absolutely necessary.Reverting to the case in hand, from the on record it is clear that death of Tuli had occurred otherwise than under normal (Emphasis supplied) There is on record to indicate that the case on hand is one of suicide by poison.The PW-10 (Medical Officer) who performed the post mortem has deposed that odour material with pungent smell was found in the stomach.The expert opined that in cases of consumption of poison, such kind of pungent smell would be found.The PW-10 admitted that if there is any delay in forwarding the viscera sample for chemical examination, the poison may not be Unfortunately, in the case on hand, the viscera was by the FSL for chemical analysis on 22nd February, 2012 that is after a period of almost five months.In a research article titled, Negative viscera report and its medico-legal aspects, it has been mentioned that in many cases, the viscera report is negative on three major basis, namely it can be procedure based, sample based or lab based.The said research paper reveals that there are in which viscera test may not reveal the of compounds from the following Sample quantities by FSL much less than those prescribed for optimal analysis Required quantity and quality of not used during sampling time and container not maintained for preservation of sample Difficulty in detection of poison due to vomiting, purging or from the system by the kidneys or due to prolonged stay in the hospital immediately prior to the death Not sending stomach wash (gastric lavage) and vomit along with viscera for examination Some organic poison decompose due to improper preservation or control Site of sample collection on the body also play an important role In postmortem many poisons present in the tissue undergo chemical changes which cannot be in routine analysis This Court in Mahabir Mandal v. State of Bihar, (1972) 1 SCC 748, looked into the observations found at page 477 of the Modis Medical Jurisprudence and edition) and held that under some if the whole of the poison has disappeared from the lungs by evaporation, or has been removed from the stomach and intestines by vomiting and purging, and after absorption has been detoxified, conjugated and eliminated from the system by the kidneys and other channels, it is possible that there may not be traces of poison.Thus, the absence of detection of poison in the viscera report alone need not be treated as a conclusive proof of the fact that the victim has not died of poison.In Mahabir Mandal (supra), this Court has ob- served as under- Empty has been made by Mr.Chari to report dated 23, 1963 of the Chemical Examiner, according to whom no poison could be in the viscera of Indira This would not, in our opinion, militate against the conclusion that the death of the was due to poisoning.There are several poisons particularly of the synthetic hyp- notics and alkaloids groups, which do not leave any signs as can be noticed on post mortem examina- tion.(Emphasis supplied) The above observation of this Court was based on the made in the Modis Medical Jurisprudence and Those were also to by this Court, which are as follows- It is quite possible that a person may die from the effects of a poison, and yet none may be found in the body after death, if the whole of the poison has disappeared from the lungs by evaporation, or has been removed from the stomach and intestines by vomiting and purging, and after absorption has been detoxified, conjugated and elimi- nated from the system by the kidneys and other channels.Certain poisons may not be in the viscera, as they have no reliable tests, while some organic poisons, especially the alkaloids and glu- cosides, may be oxidation during life or by putrefaction after death, be split up into other which have no characteris- tic reactions sufficient for their identi- fication.(Emphasis supplied) As pointed out by this Court in a number of cases, where the dies as a result of poi- soning, it is difficult to isolate the poison and recognise it.Lack of positive evi- dence in this respect would not result in throwing out the entire prosecution case, if the other cir- cumstances clearly point out the guilt of the ac- cused.According to Modis Medical Jurisprudence and 23rd Edition, Editors K. and Amrit K Patnaik, the materials should be sent to the concerned Forensic Science Laboratory, through the concerned police station as quickly as possible.Otherwise, the poison may not be during the analysis of the vis- cera, even though they may contain some poison.Ken Kulig MD, in Critical Care Secrets (Fourth Edition), 2007 states that the gastric lavage must be performed soon after ingestion to be at all in removing the drugs from the stomach.For this reason, many do not lavage patients who have overdosed if more than 1 hour has elapsed since ingestion.We are conscious of the legal that while dealing with a case of circumstantial the Court has to be A note of caution was sounded by a Bench of this Court in Raghav Tripathi v. State of P. AIR 1963 SC 74 quoting (AIR p. 89 para 60) from R. vs. Hodge (1838) 2 Law CC 227.The mind was apt to take a pleasure in adapting to one another, and even in straining them a little, if need be, to force them to form parts of one con- nected whole and the more ingenious the mind of the the more likely was it, considering such matter, to overreach and mislead itself, to supply some little link that is wanting, to take for granted some fact consistent with its previous the- ories and necessary to render them com- plete.Thus, the Court should not unwittingly fall into the same dangerous trap which the Constitu- tion Bench has cautioned to be guarded against.Considering the overall on record, we find it difficult to take the view that in the absence of any positive viscera report, the prose- cution could be said to have failed to establish its case.For the foregoing reasons, we have reached to the conclusion that we should not with the concurrent findings recorded by the two Courts below.

column2: Abhay S.Oka, J.Leave granted.Heard the learned counsel appearing for the parties.The was convicted by the Trial Court for the offence punishable under Section 6 of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act, 2012 (for short POCSO Act).The appeal against conviction by the appellant was admitted by the High Court and by the order dated 12th January, 2018, the substantive of the appellant was suspended and he was Signature Not Verified Digitally signed by Anita Malhotra ordered to be enlarged on bail.Date 180934 IST Reason Criminal Appeal SLP(Crl.)No.8609/2023 Page 1 of 5 On 7th July, 2023, the said Criminal Appeal of the year 2017 was called out before the learned Single Judge of the High Court for hearing.The Advocate for the appellant sought adjournment for four weeks.Only on the ground that the appellant is enjoying the facility of bail and that his advocate applied for adjournment, the High Court to cancel the bail.In a given case, if the advocate appearing for the seeks adjournment on untenable and unreasonable grounds, the Appellate Court is well within its power to refuse the prayer for adjournment.In such a case, one of the courses suggested by a decision of this Court in the case of Bani Singh v. State of U.P.1 can always be adopted by the High Court.The High Court has a discretion to appoint an advocate to espouse the cause of the appellant when the advocate appointed by the appellant refuses to argue the appeal on unreasonable grounds.Though the High Court has an option of considering the merits of the appeal and deciding the same on merits, the High Court could always adopt the first course of appointing an advocate to espouse the cause of the appellant.1.(1996) 4 SCC 720 Criminal Appeal SLP(Crl.)No.8609/2023 Page 2 of 5 Sub-section 1 of Section 389 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 (for short CrPC) reads thus Suspension of pending the appeal of appellant on bail - (1) Pending any appeal by a convicted person, the Appellate Court may, for reasons to be recorded by it in writing, order that the execution of the or order appealed against be suspended and, also, if he is in that he be on bail, or on his own bond.Provided that the Appellate Court shall, before releasing on bail or on his own bond a convicted person who is convicted of an offence punishable with death or imprisonment for life or imprisonment for a term of not less than ten years, shall give opportunity to the Public Prosecutor for showing cause in writing against such Provided further that in cases where a convicted person is on bail it shall be open to the Public Prosecutor to file an application for the cancellation of the bail.(underline supplied) Under sub-section 1 of Section 389, while suspending the of the who is in Jail, the Appellate Court has to enlarge the accused on bail till the final disposal of the appeal.The Criminal Appeal SLP(Crl.)No.8609/2023 Page 3 of 5 second proviso to sub-section 1 of Section 389 permits the Public Prosecutor to file an application for cancellation of the bail granted under sub-section 1.The second proviso to sub-section 1 of Section 389 is on par with sub-section 2 of Section 439 of CrPC.the Court can even Suo Motu issue a notice calling upon the accused to show cause why the bail should not be cancelled.Under no the bail granted to an accused under sub-section 1 of Section 389 can be cancelled without giving a reasonable opportunity to the accused of being heard.Unfortunately, the High Court, without even giving an opportunity of being heard to the on the issue of cancellation of bail, has straight away to cancel the bail granted to him.Such approach on the part of the High Court cannot be especially when the High Court can always deal with the situation when an adjournment is sought by the advocate for the accused at the time of final hearing of the appeal on unreasonable grounds.For the default of the advocate appointed by the accused, the Appellate Court cannot penalize the accused by proceeding to cancel his bail only on the ground that his advocate has sought adjournment and that also without giving an opportunity Criminal Appeal SLP(Crl.)No.8609/2023 Page 4 of 5 of being heard to him on the issue of cancellation of bail.
